verses.text: This is what the LORD says: For three transgressions of Moab, and for four, I will not turn back My wrath, because he burned the bones of the king of Edom to lime.
verses.comment: Moab's offense is grave: desecrating human remains was seen as an ultimate insult, violating both human dignity and God's image in mankind (Gen. 1:27).

verses.text: So I will send fire upon Moab, and it shall destroy the palaces of Kerioth; and Moab shall die amid tumult, with shoutings and the sound of the trumpet.
verses.comment: Judgment on Moab is complete and noisy—akin to apocalyptic imagery in other prophets. The fire echoes God’s consuming holiness (Heb. 12:29).

verses.text: I will cut off the ruler from its midst, and will kill all its princes with him, says the LORD.
verses.comment: God judges leaders for their actions, reminding us of the divine authority over earthly rulers (Rom. 13:1).

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: For three transgressions of Judah, and for four, I will not turn back My wrath, because they have rejected the law of the LORD and have not kept His statutes; their lies have caused them to go astray, after which their fathers walked.
verses.comment: Judah’s judgment is specifically tied to abandoning God’s revealed law—not just social evil. Spiritual infidelity is highlighted here, a foreshadowing of Christ’s call to fulfill the Law (Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: So I will send fire upon Judah, and it shall devour the palaces of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Judah, God’s chosen people, are not exempt from judgment—showing that belonging to the covenant community requires faithfulness. The temple, much later, becomes the locus of Christ’s atoning presence.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: For three transgressions of Israel, and for four, I will not turn back My wrath, because they sell the righteous for silver, and the needy for a pair of sandals.
verses.comment: Social injustice is condemned. The phrase 'sell the righteous for silver' foreshadows the betrayal of Christ for silver (Matt. 26:15), linking prophecy to fulfillment.

verses.text: They trample on the head of the poor into the dust of the earth, and push aside the afflicted. A man and his father go in to the same young woman, so as to profane My holy name.
verses.comment: Gross personal and sexual sin corrupts communal holiness. The reference to profaning God's name points to the dignity and sacredness of being God’s people.

verses.text: They lie beside every altar on garments taken in pledge, and drink wine in the house of their gods bought with fines.
verses.comment: Israel corrupts worship by using unjust gains and violating the law on pledges (see Ex. 22:26-27). The intertwining of injustice and false worship contrasts with genuine worship in Spirit and truth (John 4:24).

verses.text: Yet I destroyed the Amorite before them, whose height was like the height of the cedars, and who was strong as oaks; I destroyed his fruit above and his roots beneath.
verses.comment: Despite God’s mighty acts—the defeat of formidable enemies—Israel forgot His deliverance. The fruit/root imagery contains hints of judgment and restoration themes found in later prophets (Isa. 11:1).

verses.text: Also I brought you up out of the land of Egypt, and led you forty years through the wilderness, to possess the land of the Amorite.
verses.comment: This recalls the Exodus, central to scriptural salvation history, later spiritually fulfilled in Christ as the True Deliverer (Luke 9:31).

verses.text: And I raised up some of your sons as prophets, and some of your young men as Nazirites. Is it not so, people of Israel? says the LORD.
verses.comment: Prophets and Nazirites were set apart for God’s service, prefiguring the later call to holiness and sacrificial living (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: But you made the Nazirites drink wine, and commanded the prophets, saying, 'Do not prophesy.'
verses.comment: Israel’s rejection of consecrated people foreshadows later resistance to God’s messengers—including Christ Himself (Luke 11:47-49).

verses.text: Behold, I will press you down in your place, as a cart full of sheaves presses down.
verses.comment: Oppression imagery indicates the weighty consequences of sin—God’s justice is not arbitrary, but proportional and purposeful.

verses.text: Flight will perish from the swift; the strong will not strengthen his force, nor will the mighty save himself.
verses.comment: Human resources and strength fail in the face of divine judgment, underscoring the need for dependence on the Lord alone—an invitation to humility and surrender.

verses.text: He who handles the bow will not stand, nor will the swift of foot escape; nor will he who rides the horse save his life.
verses.comment: Skill and speed offer no escape; salvation comes not from human means but from God alone (Ps. 33:16–17).

verses.text: Even the bravest among the warriors will flee naked on that day, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Humiliation in judgment is total. The image anticipates the vulnerability of even the strong, echoing spiritual themes of dependence and repentance. Note Mark 14:51-52, where fleeing naked symbolizes abandonment of earthly security.
